nodes.text: High public and external debt levels are systematically associated with lower economic growth, with different inflation outcomes across advanced and emerging economies
Method: assembled a new multi-country historical dataset on gross central government debt covering 44 countries and about 200 years with over 3,700 annual observations
Result: Across countries, public debt above roughly 90 percent of GDP is associated with median GDP growth about one percentage point lower and mean growth several percentage points lower
Result: For advanced economies, there is no systematic relationship between very high public debt (above 90 percent) and higher inflation as a group
Result: For emerging market countries, high public debt levels coincide with significantly higher inflation, suggesting fiscal dominance

Result: For emerging markets, gross external debt thresholds are lower: external debt above 60 percent of GDP reduces annual growth by about two percent and above 90 percent roughly halves growth; inflation rises mainly when external debt exceeds 90 percent

Evidence: Summary statistics and figures for 20 advanced economies (1946–2009) and for 24 emerging markets show median and mean growth fall markedly in the highest debt categories and differing inflation patterns between groups
Evidence: Long-run country-level table (up to two centuries for many countries) yields similar conclusions: average growth when debt over 90 percent is much lower than when debt is low

Claim: The relationship is nonlinear and consistent with a debt intolerance mechanism where hitting debt tolerance limits raises market interest rates, forcing fiscal adjustment or default and lowering growth

Method: used measures including central government gross debt, reported gross external debt (public and private), and separated analyses by country group; external debt series for advanced countries too short to compute comparable thresholds

Result / Evidence: Private sector deleveraging after financial crises (illustrated with US private debt 1916–2009) is associated with lower growth and higher unemployment and may further damp medium-term growth
Evidence / Result: Public debt rose sharply during the 2007–2009 crisis—about a 75 percent increase in crisis countries and about 20 percent even in noncrisis countries between 2007 and 2009

Conclusion: The sharp run-up in public debt from the 2007–2009 crisis is likely an enduring legacy and raises the risk of persistently lower growth because countries seldom "grow" their way out of high debt

Policy implication / Claim: Traditional debt management matters—reliance on short-term borrowing and shortening debt maturity increases vulnerability to sudden confidence crises and should be a public policy priority

Limitation: Data limitations include scarce long-run private domestic debt series across countries and insufficient time series on external debt for advanced economies to calculate external thresholds
